report_title: Boiler and Heat Exchanger Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Manufacturers produce boilers and heat exchangers for heating liquids for the industrial, energy and commercial markets. During recent years, the industry has experienced significant levels of volatility. Manufacturers rely on various industries, resulting in a diversified revenue stream. The pandemic affected multiple downstream markets, particularly vehicle manufacturing. Similarly, rising inflation and interest rates have led to declines in the nonresidential construction sector. However, the war in Ukraine led to a global slowdown in oil production, boosting demand for the domestic oil and gas sector, a major market of the industry. Overall, boiler and heat exchanger manufacturing revenue has lagged at a CAGR of 2.9% to $8.4 billion over the five years to 2024, including a dip of 1.2% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Significant Revenue Volatility Levels Impacts Manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Boiler and heat exchanging manufacturers have endured significant revenue fluctuations during the current period, specifically with substantial losses in 2020. Strict tariffs on Chinese-produced boilers and heat exchangers caused the value of imports to fall, as imported products became comparatively higher priced than domestically produced goods, benefiting domestic manufacturers. The pandemic resulted in declines in industry profit, mainly caused by limitations on manufacturing, trade and new nonresidential construction.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Volatile Downstream Markets Cause Revenue Fluctuations
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The vehicle industry is the largest market segment of manufacturers. The pandemic, input shortages, growing inflation and increasing interest rates discourage the purchase of new vehicles, lowering production and negatively affecting heat exchanger manufacturers. Industrial manufacturing slowed down due to pandemic-induced restrictions. Industrial manufacturing has not returned to pre-pandemic levels, putting downward pressure on industry revenue. Demand from food production facilities faced little change due to its inelastic nature. The segment has a lower impact on manufacturing activity and does not contribute heavily to revenue. However, it prevented further losses. Oil and gas production companies were directly impacted by increasing crude oil prices during the pandemic and then again with the war in Ukraine.

The price of steel, a main input in the manufacturing of boilers and heat exchangers, has changed rapidly in recent years. Lower production capacity combined with significant demand for home appliances and construction caused the price of steel to rise more than 90.0% in 2021. However, steel prices have fallen over the past five years, including plummeting over 40.0% in 2024. Falling steel prices constrain revenue as manufacturers can't price products as aggressively.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Manufacturers Navigate Changes in Trade Conditions
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Boiler and heat exchanger's revenue is highly diversified, including a large influence from international markets due to the globalized nature of the industry. Tariffs imposed on China by the Trump administration lowered imports from China, now the second-largest import source of boilers and heat exchangers. The price of Chinese goods became comparatively higher than domestically produced boilers and heat exchangers, boosting demand for domestic manufacturers. The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) benefits domestic manufacturers as the trade agreement lowers exporting costs among the trading partners. International downstream markets based in Mexico and Canada often prefer US-produced boilers and heat exchangers, due to their high-quality standards.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Positive Economic Conditions Will Support Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: However, lower oil production in Russia supports demand for domestic oil, boosting revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STRICT EFFICIENCY STANDARDS FORCE MANUFACTURERS TO ADAPT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Higher efficiency standards in the residential construction sector will likely spill over to other segments, driving sales as buyers adapt to the new standards. Manufacturers meeting the new efficiency standards will increase their chances of winning contracts in the tendering process, possibly harming smaller manufacturers with lower operating capabilities.

A weakening US dollar will boost sales in markets abroad as the comparative price of domestically produced boilers and heat exchangers falls. The depreciation of the US dollar will result in domestic buyers purchasing more US-produced boilers and heat exchangers, as they will become more price competitive and offer higher quality. The US government plans on revisiting trade discussions with the Chinese government to lift or reduce the tariffs on multiple goods. Lowering tariffs will boost demand for Chinese boilers and heat exchangers, harming domestic manufacturers.

industry_definition: This industry primarily manufactures boilers and heat exchangers. Boilers are closed vessels where the fluid is heated, while heat exchangers enable thermal energy to be transferred between fluids while keeping them separate. Industry products are used in a variety of industrial, energy and commercial markets.
key_trends: Buyers emphasize the need for quality products, maintaining demand high regardless of a strong US dollar. This has supported the growth of domestic manufacturers.
Manufacturers often specialize in specific markets, as the industry market base is widely diverse. Specialization enables manufacturers to offer products that meet industry-specific needs.
Manufacturers encountered steep declines amid the pandemic. Declines in nonresidential construction and utilities construction throughout the period resulted in lagging industry revenue.
Hostile trade conditions with China have benefited domestic producers. The price of Chinese imports increased significantly due to tariffs, creating more opportunities for US manufacturers.
Acquisition trends continue, with large producers looking to expand their capabilities. This includes improving their technological capabilities to better serve multiple markets.
Major manufacturers look to innovate, creating products that better process fuel and fuel alternatives. These changes will allow companies to remain competitive as environmental regulations tighten.

Tariffs imposed on Chinese-produced boilers benefit domestic producers. Before the tariffs, China was the largest importer in the industry; price increases encouraged buyers to purchase boilers and heat exchangers from various different countries such as Mexico and Canada.

The pandemic resulted in highly volatile steel prices, supporting changes in revenue. In 2021, steel prices reached historically high levels, enabling manufacturers to pass down higher costs to buyers. Profit has lagged due to falling downstream demand from construction markets. In addition, a strengthening US dollar has hindered industry exports, putting downward pressure on revenue and profit.
Wage costs climb despite automation as manufacturers look to boost productivity. Revenue has fallen at a faster rate than wages, resulting in wages climbing as a share of revenue.

Manufacturers based near ports enjoy lower exporting costs and easy access to imported inputs. As a result, producers based in the West, Southeast and Mid-Atlantic can increase their profit margin. Proximity to downstream markets limits transportation costs. Manufacturers basing operations nearby major buyers can build stronger relations and benefit from fewer costs.
Losses in the vehicle sector negatively impacted manufacturers. Vehicle production requires heat exchangers; therefore, vehicle demand directly impacts heat exchanger sales.
Nuclear energy continues to fall in popularity as consumers grow wary of it. Downstream consumers maintain safety concerns.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The vehicular market includes the manufacturing of commercial, off-highway, consumer and other vehicles, which use heat exchangers for cooling hydraulic and quenching oil, cooling machine coolants and other processes.
Buyers in the Commercial Sector include healthcare facilities, office buildings, education facilities that use commercial boilers and water cooling systems with heat exchangers.

Industries within this market include data centers, chemical manufacturing, paper manufacturing, food processors, energy sector. The food sector relies on boilers and heat exchangers for refrigeration and wet corn milling, creating consistent demand from food production facilities.

Other markets include wholesalers, residential consumers and other buyers not included in the markets outlined above. Declines in residential construction have hindered industry revenue from this market.

products_and_services.product_description: Heat exchangers ensure efficient heat transfer from one fluid to another without permitting the mixing of the fluids. Its main uses are refrigeration, air conditioning, space heating, power production, petroleum refineries and other chemical processing.

international_trade_points.trade_title: China slows down amid the pandemic and high tariffs
international_trade_points.trade_description: China is a major global producer of steel, a main input of boilers and heat exchangers. In 2018, the Trump administration started a trade war with China, placing an additional 25.0% tariff on various industry-relevant products. Imports from China slowed down significantly once the tariffs went into effect.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Manufacturers have encountered negative trade conditions
international_trade_points.trade_description: Mexico and Canada benefit from United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), a trade agreement that lowers trade barriers between the countries. Overall industry imports plummeted due to the pandemic. In 2022, the value of imports grew significantly faster than domestic sales, driven mainly by a strong dollar.

Mexico and Canada are the most significant export destinations, receiving more than one-third of industry exports. Manufacturers in the United States often produce high-quality and high-value products, making exports more attractive to downstream companies that focus on quality.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Current conditions will change but continue to hinder domestic producers
international_trade_points.trade_description: In retaliation to the tariffs imposed by the Trump administration, the Chinese government put in place similar tariffs, making the price of US-produced boilers and heat exchangers jump. A strengthening US dollar has made products less attractive to downstream consumers abroad.

business_locations.location_description: Oklahoma has a high concentration of food production facilities, luring in manufacturers specializing in food processing equipment.

Texas is home to many downstream markets, including industrial product manufacturing, refined petroleum, industrial organic chemicals, oil field machinery and other petrochemical subsectors. Proximity to Mexico, one of the most significant export destinations, lowers transportation costs and supports manufacturers in the region.

Manufacturers in the Southeast benefit from basing operations near population-dense areas, as they can lower transportation costs by placing establishments closer to a large customer base. The region has access to multiple trade ports, lowering export transportation costs and simplifying the input importing process.
The Mid-Atlantic has access to some of the largest trade ports in the United States, making it an attractive location for manufacturing industries to receive raw materials and ship exports.

The Great Lakes is a popular region for manufacturing activity. Downstream industries purchase boilers and heat exchangers for the manufacturing of multiple products. Canada is the largest export destination of the industry. Proximity to Canada lowers transportation expenses, increasing profit and making manufacturers more price competitive. Ohio is a major steel producer and a pioneer in oil refining, both inputs for boilers and heat exchangers. Easy access to inputs further lower transportation costs, boosting profitability.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Department of Energy (DOE) increased the minimum efficiency standards for residential boilers and furnaces. These new efficiency standards won't significantly impact revenue due to the small size of the.

The Clean Air Act requires compliance with air quality standards and empowers the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish and enforce limits on the emission of pollutants. The act establishes regulations for sulfur and nitrogen oxides and strict requirements for ozone emissions and other toxic materials.

The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of pollutants into the surface water. The act establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, in addition to water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

Boilers and heat exchangers used in energy production, nuclear energy, utilities management and other critical infrastructure are more frequently and easily selected for purchase if manufactured in the United States due to high-quality standards.

Manufacturers must ensure the safety of workers, mainly through noise and dust standards. Similarly, manufacturers are required to provide proper training on the use of machinery and procedure to reduce workplace risks.

volatility_points.volatility_title: MAJOR EVENTS IMPACT DEMAND FROM DOWNSTREAM CONSUMERS
volatility_points.volatility_description: - Input shortages in the vehicle production sector caused vehicle prices to rise, causing demand for heat exchangers to fall. - Increasing interest rates and inflation discourage big ticket purchases, such as cars, slowing down demand for heat exchangers. - The petroleum refining process requires the use of boilers. Increases in oil prices reflect high demand for refined petroleum, driving boiler sales. - Manufacturing activity slumped over the past five years, hindering boiler and heat exchanger manufacturers. As a result, some manufacturers were forced to exit the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INPUT PRICES ARE HIGHLY VOLATILE, AFFECTING REVENUE
volatility_points.volatility_description: - Changes in the price of steel impact industry revenue, as lower steel prices limit how aggressive manufacturers can be with product pricing. - The pandemic caused the price of steel to fall, lowering revenue. In addition, the price of steel is expected to plummet in 2024, further hindering revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have been focusing on developing and improving features that increase efficiency and lower operating costs. One of the newest developments includes condensing boilers that extract additional heat from exhaust gases by condensing its hot water vapor, lowering fuel costs. Engineers have made progress in creating more efficient models of heat exchangers using heat transfer simulation software to better maintain heat during the process and use fewer resources.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Imports represent one-fourth of domestic demand and revenue and import penetration is currently at a moderate level.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: The industry is fairly cyclical, and revenue is heavily dependent on demand from food manufacturing and from industrial manufacturing activity.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in research and development to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Companies have devoted resources to product research and development to refine their cost structure, but less activity in new products. Consumer preference is shifting toward electric and renewable energy-powered heat exchange.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of steel is volatile, causing uncertainty in costs and hinders companies from planning their output levels. Securing fixed-price deals with steel manufacturers may protect your company from further price shocks.

FAQs.question: How does your company invest in technology, such as robotic assembly and simulated heat flow software, to establish a competitive edge over your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry are increasing investments in specialized technologies to refine cost structure and edge out imports. New technologies, such as heat flow modeling software and autonomous assembly, are expected to allow companies to increase the efficiency of their manufacturing processes.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology, such as cloud computing and data analytics, in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Companies are increasingly relying on cloud-based and other information technology to store and share information. Analyzing customer needs precisely may enable your company to design a heat exchange or boiler, which more precisely fits the client's need and thus can be more efficient or capable.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: Companies are ensuring that they are in compliance with efficiency regulations to be able to secure future contracts. As the current administration is expected to tighten efficiency and other environmental regulations, companies in this industry will need to stay abreast of the regulatory landscape.

FAQs.question: What effect have international tariffs had on your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: Tariffs significantly reduced imports from China. Monitoring changes in these tariffs can warn companies about changes in demand and access to low-cost inputs.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatility in the price of steel negatively impacts profit margin and prevents companies from efficiently planning their costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margin can decline if a company cannot relay input costs downstream.

FAQs.question: How do you attract and retain qualified staff? How do you keep wages competitive?
FAQs.answer: Operator success depends on the skill of engineering, technical and marketing employees who actively assist customers in specifying their needs and in determining the appropriate products to meet those needs.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: To gain business, manufacturers must build quality into their products, materials, specifications, safety features, parts, delivery and service. While experiencing single product failures is to be expected, the way your company responds to and assists customers during these moments defines your reputation more than at any other time.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? Is your technical expertise to a world standard?
FAQs.answer: Access to the latest technology is required for operators to make improvements in product capabilities and specifications. Progression in new technologies, such as robotic welding and heat flow modeling software, is expected to allow industry companies to make further improvements to their products.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your overall revenue comes from exports? Are your prices competitive compared with lower-cost operators abroad? How do international tariffs affect your exports?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its major trading partners. When the value of the US dollar rises, there is greater import competition.

FAQs.question: How many of your products burn fuels? Are these products easily able to be transformed to use electric power?
FAQs.answer: Increasingly tight environmental standards and changing consumer sentiments are moving away from traditional fuel-fired boilers for electric models, which can be powered by renewable energy sources. Operators whose product lines are unable to be swapped over may experience dramatically fewer business and regulatory challenges in the coming decade.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in steel prices affected you in the past? Are you able to pass higher input costs on to consumers?
FAQs.answer: The majority of the industry's products are composed of steel and purchases of various flat and rolled steel inputs constitute a large component of the average company's cost structure.
